p:
The results of this study demonstrate that a peptide-based vaccine designed to induce influenza-specific T cell immunity (in the absence of inducing antibody responses against HA) can provide some protection against influenza. At least one other peptide-based universal influenza vaccine candidate inducing T cell immunity has completed phase I and II trials, but that vaccine has not demonstrated efficacy via a primary outcome
23, 24 . However, the ability of peptide vaccines to alter the functionality of T cells has been previously observed
25 , and data from various studies demonstrate that low doses induce high T cell avidity while high peptide concentrations favor low avidity T cells and inhibition of the T cell proliferative response
26 . This can affect the available T cell repertoire in vivo and subsequent pathogen clearance. A high and low zone tolerance after immunization with different doses of antigen exists and must be empirically determined
27 . The optimal dose and formulation of FLU-v was identified in preclinical and clinical studies
20, 21 . The dose administered in this trial, 500â€‰ug, provided the best T cell-driven immune responses that correlated with reduction in virus shedding and symptoms in a small Phase IB H3N2 influenza human challenge
21 .
